webTitle: FTSE falls back once more as eurozone doubts grow and UK retail sales disappoint

fields.standfirst: Hopes of progress at EU summit begin to dim while high street sales in April fall sharply
fields.body:
Leading shares have lost almost all of Tuesday's gains, as hopes of serious moves towards resolving the eurozone crisis faded and UK retail sales came in sharply lower than expected.

The FTSE 100 jumped sharply ahead of today's EU summit as investors bet on a possible agreement to promote growth and even perhaps agree to issue eurobonds. But the resistance to the idea by Germany seems unlikely to allow that to happen.

Meanwhile UK retail sales fell at their fastest for more than two years in April, down 2.3% compared to a forecast fall of 0.8%, as the wet weather dampened enthusiasm for shopping.

So the leading index is now down 85 points at 5318.28. Markets were under pressure from the start, following some confusion over remarks by former Greek prime minister Lucas Papademos, who initially seemed to suggest countries were making continency plans for a possible Greek exit from the euro. Later he appeared to say no such plans were underway. The last thing markets like is uncertainty, so this has not gone down well.

Mining companies, among Tuesday's gainers as China indicated it would bring forward infrastructure spending, are now almost inevitably the biggest fallers. Kazakhmys is down 37p at 700.5p and Vedanta Resources has lost 50p to 997p.

But leading the way lower is Man, down 4.55p at 73.1p. On Tuesday a couple of downbeat broker notes unsettled the shares, which have been poor performers on worries about its growth outlook and concerns about fund outflows. Now Moody's has joined in, saying it was continuing its rating review of the business and would include this week's news of Man's proposed acqusition of FRM Holdings.

webTitle: Burberry targets up-and-coming luxury markets

fields.standfirst: Trenchcoat maker plans store opening spree in Brazil and Mexico and sticks with expansion strategy despite euro fears
fields.body:
Burberry is embarking on a store opening spree in Brazil and Mexico this year as the British brand targets up-and-coming luxury markets.

The famous trenchcoat maker said it would open up to 10 stores in Central and Latin America as part of a £200m investment that will also see existing stores in shopping capitals such as London move to larger premises. The investment will see Burberry increase its retail selling space by up to 14% this year.

Luxury goods shares have wobbled in recent months over worries that turmoil in the eurozone could help trigger an economic slowdown in emerging markets such as China, where runaway demand for designer clothes and handbags has helped counter weaker sales trends in traditionally important luxury markets such as the US and Europe.

Burberry's chief executive, Angela Ahrendts, highlighted tough trading in both Italy and Korea but said: "While we remain vigilant about the external environment, we will continue to invest." Her comments came as Burberry reported a 26% increased in profits to £376m on sales of nearly £1.9bn.

Burberry said the cost and timing of the investment in new stores would result in a lower operating margin in the first six months of the year, a warning that saw the shares drop more than 5% in early trading.

Under the leadership of Ahrendts, an American who joined from US clothing giant Liz Claiborne six years ago, the brand has shed its reliance on raincoats and its trademark camel, red and black check, thanks to edgy advertising featuring young actors such as Birdsong star Eddie Redmayne. Sales of men's and womenswear both increased by more than 25% during the year.

Ahrendts has also pulled the 156-year-old brand started by Thomas Burberry into the 21st century by broadcasting its runway shows in 3D live on the internet and launching several spin-off websites, including Art of the Trench. Sales and visitor numbers to its main website increased more than 10%, the company said, while the number of its Facebook fans broke through 12 million.

Ahrendts said markets such as Brazil, Mexico and India were still in the "investment phase". The brand, which sells alligator skin shopper bags for £12,000 and diamond set watches for £1,600, has already conquered the Asia Pacific region, which is the brand's most important sales area with growth of more than 40% during the year. Asian tourists, predominantly from China, are also Burberry's biggest customers in major tourist cities, such as Paris, New York and London.

Simon Irwin, an analyst at Liberium Capital, said the margin guidance was a "major surprise" as full-year results were "bang in line". "This we assume is the result of the flagship opening programme which will add costs early with the company, presumably, taking a cautious approach to the sales ramp-up." Irwin expected to trim his profit forecasts for the year by 5% but added: "We regard this as principally a function of the timing of growth, rather a material change in long-term margins or returns."

webTitle: Cove Energy jumps 10% as Thailand's PTT trumps rival Shell with £1.22bn offer

fields.standfirst: Battle to secure East African specialist takes a new twist and investors hope for further bid moves
fields.body:
Just when it seemed Royal Dutch Shell had snapped up key assets in East Africa with the agreed purchase of Cove Energy, rival bidder PTT of Thailand has trumped its offer, rekindling the prospect of a further takeover battle.

Hours before a deadline for Cove investors to accept Shell's bid, PTT has offered £1.22bn or 240p a share, topping Shell's 220p deal. Cove's management has now changed its backing from Shell to the Thai group. Cove has an 8.5% stake in a gas find off Mozambique, and while Shell saw a deal as a way into East Africa, PTT wants Cove's resources to help power Thailand's economy. Werner Riding at Peel Hunt said:

The competitive tension surrounding what is a highly-prized strategic gas asset offshore Mozambique is conspiring to create exceptional value for shareholders. Responding to today's improved offer we increase our target price to 240p a share [from 220p] and maintain our hold recommendation.
We highlight that today is the last day that Cove shareholders have to accept the current Shell offer; following which time the offer will lapse. This does not preclude Shell from submitting a new offer in response to PTT and so there remains the distinct possibility that a further counter-offer could transpire.

Cove has climbed 24.25p to 248.25p on the news, suggesting the market is also hoping for yet another increased offer. Stuart Joyner at Investec said Shell had the flexibility to improve its offer to around 300p a share, based on a recent resource upgrade.

webTitle: Quarter of deposits withdrawn from Greek banks

fields.standfirst: But while Greek deposits have fallen over two years, those at Portuguese banks have risen to record highs and Spanish and Italian deposits have fallen just 3% and 2%
fields.body:
Almost 25% of deposits have been withdrawn from Greek banks in the last two years but outflows have been small from other banking systems inside the so-called periphery, according to Barclays analysts.

While Greek deposits are falling, those at Portuguese lenders have risen to record highs, and Spanish and Italian deposits have fallen 3% and 2% respectively.

"Talk of a possible exit of Greece from the European monetary union has sparked fears about deposit outflows from other peripheral countries, but these concerns are not new and evidence does not indicate material outflows from Spain, Italy, Ireland, and Portugal," the analysts said.

Even so, fears of a Greek exit from the eurozone have sparked debate about whether there should be an EU-wide guarantee for the single currency area. At the moment, the €100,000 deposit guarantees are paid for by national banking systems – which should prevent the need for any deposits to be withdrawn – but there are suggestions that the cost should be spread across the eurozone.

Barclays analysts said this would not make a difference: "An EU-wide deposit guarantee scheme could be on the agenda in upcoming meetings. We believe such a proposal would fail to solve the challenges facing the current European deposit insurance scheme. While it would enhance the creditworthiness of the guarantor, it would still not protect against currency redenomination."

Economist at UBS believe that Greece will remain in the euro because the costs of exit are "excessive" to both Greece and the euro area. Local opinion polls show the majority of Greeks want to remain in the single currency. The UBS economists argue that if Greece considers leaving, the markets and bank depositors will all anticipate the event. "This anticipation of exit would likely result in economic disorder," the UBS analysts said.

"The anticipation, and not the act of leaving, will in all probability lead to the cessation of international trade in the conventional sense, the ability of the government to raise any finance in the markets, and bank runs."

The UBS analysts point out that the concerns are not about the strength of banks themselves. "In the event of a Greek exit, contagion risks clearly exist. There seems to be a great deal of official complacency about the ability of firewalls to prevent this. The risk lies in the contagion of bank runs. Bank runs, if they occur, will likely arise because of existential risks about the euro, rather than solvency or liquidity risks about banking systems," the UBS economists warned.
